subject: linear_algebra
statementHtml: Given a system of linear equations Ax = b, use Gauss-Jordan elimination to find the reduced row echelon form (RREF) and determine if it is unique.
hints: Start by performing elementary row operations on A until you reach RREF.
Check if the resulting matrix has a pivot in each column. If not, there may be multiple solutions or no solution at all.
If the RREF is unique, can you use it to find the inverse of A?
solutionHtml:
To solve this problem, we will perform Gauss-Jordan elimination on the matrix A.

  • Perform elementary row operations until reaching RREF:
    • \[ \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{bmatrix} \]\[ \Rightarrow \] \[\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\]
  • Check for uniqueness:
    • \[ \text{Unique RREF} \Rightarrow \text{Inverse exists} \]
",
answerShort: The reduced row echelon form is unique, and the inverse of A can be found." },

subject: linear_algebra
statementHtml: Given a system of linear equations Ax = b, use Gauss-Jordan elimination to find the reduced row echelon form (RREF) and determine if it is unique.
hints: Start by performing elementary row operations on A until you reach RREF.
Check if any rows become all zeros during the process. If so, eliminate those rows.
When you're done, check if the resulting matrix has a pivot in each column.
solutionHtml:
Let's work through an example:

A = \[\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \\ 5 & 6 \end{bmatrix}\]

We'll perform the following row operations:

  • \(R_2 \leftarrow R_2 - 3R_1\)
  • \(R_3 \leftarrow R_3 - 5R_1\)

This gives us:

A = \[\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 0 & 2 \\ 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}\]

Now we can eliminate the second row, since it's all zeros:

A = \[\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}\]

This is our RREF. Since each column has a pivot (the leading entry), we know the matrix is in unique form.

",
answerShort: The reduced row echelon form of A is unique." },

subject: linear_algebra
statementHtml: Given a system of linear equations Ax = b, use Gauss-Jordan elimination to find the reduced row echelon form (RREF) and determine if it is unique.
hints: Start by applying elementary row operations to transform the matrix into upper triangular form.
Use the fact that the RREF is unique to conclude that the inverse exists.
Verify your answer by checking that the product of the transformed matrix with the original vector b yields the same result as the original system.
solutionHtml:
To find the RREF, we apply elementary row operations:

  • \[R_1 \leftarrow R_1 + 2R_2\]
  • \[R_2 \leftarrow R_2 - R_1\]

The resulting matrix is in RREF. Since the RREF is unique, we can conclude that the inverse exists.

",
answerShort: The reduced row echelon form is unique and the inverse exists." },
